title.rendered: New Logo and Packaging for Cazadores by Duffy & Partners

content.rendered:
First produced in 1922 by Don José María in Jalisco, Mexico, Cazadores is a premium line of Tequila originally only available in Mexico. In 2002 the brand name and the production facility in Jalisco were purchased by Bacardi Limited with the goal to bring the product to international markets. This past September Cazadores introduced a new logo and bottle designed by Minneapolis, MN-based Duffy & Partners.

The most distinctive feature of Tequila CAZADORES new look is a redesigned bottle with a unique and stylish shape that showcases the spirit’s premium essence. An embossed neck references 1922, reminding consumers of a long-standing heritage, rich tradition and time-tested recipe. Embossed on the back of the new bottle are words proudly emphasizing the tequila’s provenance from Los Altos de Jalisco and the 100 percent agave promise. A new cork closure adds a rustic yet premium appeal.

Carefully developed graphics communicate CAZADORES high quality and simplicity. The new label highlights the tequila’s iconic stamp, the powerful and majestic stag Don José María admired from the window of his adobe farmhouse in Los Altos, superimposed above a new logotype debossed on thick, distressed paper. Bold colors help consumers better differentiate the four expressions: blanco, reposado, añejo and extra añejo. Finally, Spanish language labeling celebrates the tequila’s genuine Mexican origin.

Bacardi Limited press release

The previous logo wasn’t too bad. With a little letter-spacing it could have been pretty good; if it had any issues perhaps it was that it wasn’t macho enough. The new logo certainly ups its macho-ness with a more spiky wordmark reminiscent of the prickly agave plant. If the “A” were better resolved — it’s too top-heavy — this would be a fabulous wordmark but I find them too distracting. It would have also been nice to see a flat version with a more streamlined chiseled approach instead of the gradient which gets a little muddied given the slender structure of the letters. Still, it’s an attention-grabbing wordmark that sits really well on the label.

The biggest improvement comes in the packaging. There was nothing premium about the previous bottle, with its haphazard typography and dated layout. The stag — which the original distiller saw from his window prancing around the agave fields — remains the central figure but has been redrawn with a more confident pose and great detail. Behind him is a woodcut illustration that seems to be from a different project but works surprisingly well in layout. The label is finished off with some Mrs Eaves, which I haven’t seen used in years. The embossed neck is pretty nice too.

Overall, the brand has been decidedly elevated to compete with the preferred bourbons of the world and establish tequila as not just a compulsory shot beverage but something that deserves to be enjoyed slowly while picturing stags running across fields of agave.
